reviewText:
Shadowgrounds is a fairly classic top down shooter in a style we have all come to know over the years. You run around a number of linear locations stopping every few rooms to fight off a throng of aliens looking to bite your face off. It is all a little too familiar and unfortunately it becomes tiresome rather quickly.

The gameplay is very much just that, you run around, shoot aliens, pick up ammo and health and occasionally upgrade your weapons. It's all very generic and something we have seen too many times before.

Where Shadowgrounds tries to stand apart from the rest is through the use of atmospheric lighting, or to say it in layman's terms, the game is very dark. At times it's completely pitch black on your screen except for the small cone from your flashlight. It's a fairly well executed feature but being a top down shooter you never really feel those horror elements that the game is trying to provoke.

The soundtrack does it's best to add to the scary mood but ultimately cannot overcome the game's basic design problems.

In the end, Shadowgrounds is a tired game in a tired genre, although it tries to do something new with the horror elements it never really hits home and you'll find yourself with just another mediocre top down shooter that's all about pumping massive hordes of alien invaders full of lead.

reviewText:
It's a budget and overtly campy game, allright. But it still gets the job done.

Even though the engine behind it shows its age nowadays, Shadowgrounds offers passable visuals with slick lighting and shadow effects, a setting and a threat that's clearly inspired by the 80's sci-fi classic Aliens (which is always a good thing in my book) and most importantly, enjoyable (if mostly repetitive) top-down action that's backed up with responsive controls and relevant mechanics to keep it interesting (i.e., rolling and the weapon upgrades).

On the con side, the story is a cliched one and it is presented through uninspired cutscenes with half-hearted voice acting. It only serves as a backbone for introducing challenges and an excuse for killing stuff. Albeit mostly boring, it comes with a nice twist in the end that I enjoyed.

Even though not as polished as one might think by looking at the screenshots, Shadowgrounds is a justifiable purchase on a budget price. It's a fine little time-waster that evokes the nostalgia of the classic top-down shooters of the bygone days. Just don't get your hopes that high up and enjoy your relaxed six-hour ride.

reviewText:
The graphical fidelity and mechanics found in this game might not be the best or most interesting by today's standards, though the lighting is still pretty good, but the atmosphere still holds and is what I found most compelling about this game.

I saw a couple instances where the enemies just kinda derped around and didn't attack me, one guy just kinda charged past me and faceplanted into a door, but most of the time they act fairly intelligently and they sometimes even try to flank you--had a couple manage to sneak up on me and take a bite or two. The first boss fight was pretty tough, if fairly repetitive (he has a pattern of attack you need to learn and dance around). They give you up to 4 respawns if you die and the boss' health does not regenerate, but those extra lives are imo more than balanced by the fact that you can't get any more ammo on a respawn (unless you backtrack trying to look for it, I guess). This was also on Medium difficulty, so I would expect Hard to give fewer attempts.

The game's supply of med kits and ammo has been fairly reasonable up to this point. It would likely have been more tense and thereby more thrilling on Medium difficulty if I'd had a couple fewer med kits and a bit less ammo, but I'm guessing playing on Hard would fix that. I do plan on finishing the game on Medium and if the rest of the game feels as good as the first hour I'll probably replay it on Hard. Btw at first it seems like you're getting way too much rifle ammo, stacking up over 500 at times, but you really do burn through it quick. And you might want to save as much ammo as possible for the boss fight.

Got this game as part of a discounted Frostbite bundle along with Trine and so far both games have been very enjoyable, in different ways. Kudos to Frostbite for making such distinct games that are almost polar opposites yet both styles are very solid (one a tense, atmospheric shooter and the other a relaxing, beautiful platformer).

Pricing is a highly subjective matter, I think, especially on older titles like this, but if the price agrees with you and/or you find it on sale and you think you might like an oldschool shooter with a dark atmosphere and an isometric perspective, then yeah I'd highly recommend giving this game a try.

Turn off the light, put on some headphones, crank up the in-game music, and I think you'll have a good time shooting some creepy crawlies.

reviewText:
Shadowgrounds is a fun, retro shooter. It's presented in a top down format, rather than as a FPS. The graphics are not world class, but do the job nicely. Likewise the story is certainly cliche - a space outpost is overrun by murderous aliens with a few survivors left to fight back and get out alive - but it is presented in a nice way and kept me entertained.

I would recommend using a game controller with this game. For me that worked great vs. a bit of frustration with keyboard and mouse.

I found the game to be slightly challenging without becoming frustrating. Each level gives you four respawns which reset for each new level. If/when you die you respawn a short distance from where you died and the level is exactly as when you died. In other words, any enemies you nerfed are still dead, etc. If you use up all your respawns (I assume) you must restart the level. There is no saving during a level, so you must either complete the current level or if you need to close the program you'll be forced to restart at the beginning. Due to this, my playtime is padded as I left the game running in the background a few times when I needed to step away.

There is a decent amount of variety in that there are about a dozen weapons to find and use and various upgrades to buy for each weapon. You won't have enough upgrade points to max out every weapon, so some thought needs to be used in deciding which to buy.

The enemies come in about six or seven different types which most of those types having several toughness levels. Throw in a few boss fights over the course of the game and it maintains interest over the half dozen or so hours it takes to run through.

If you can pick this up for a buck or two, I would go for it. Nice few days of fun to be had.

reviewText:
Shadowgrounds is an action over the head shooter from Frozenbyte that got a lot of mixed reviews so I got curious and had to review it myself as well.

Indeed the game is a bag that can give you mixed feelings. The intro starts off wich seems to be the setting for your basic military experiment/conspiracy, which even though it has written low budget all over it, it still kind of sets the games premises on pretty good.

The menu is looking ok as well and the background always keeps it a bit interesting and makes you hope something is going to happen . The first thing you will notice is that it DOES NOT have a save option.Yes, in this game you cannot save. You just have a couple of lives/respawns after wich it is game over. Like in the good old PlayStation Arcade games. This may put off a lot of people because the game can be surprisingly hard at some points, but for people like me it is a welcoming challenge.

For all the others, well at least there is a save progress at the start of each level at least.

The story starts off with the hero (Tyler) , a former military , current mechanic guy , beeng sent to fix some random generators with his buddies. The starting tone was very creepy and reminded me of a Dead Space atmosphere, which was great to notice, considering that this game is definetly not a triple A title. You fix the generators and notice that all the sudden there are bodies and blood everywhere,and surprisingly enough there is an alien invasion on your planet. You meet the army and start cleaning up. While not the most original type of story (has Doom 3) written all over it, the story holds up surprisingly well.

Moving on to the characters. All of them, including Tyler, seem very under developed. The game tries to tell you something at the start to make you care,but it just fails to deliver or generally fails at the character development section.

Graphic wise, everything seems decent, even though most of the graphics seem a bit washed up,even for a top down shooter. The details to the terrain/rooms are quite astonishing at some points. Overall the graphic,while not impressive in any way,does its job, just because of the attention to detail.The character models look just really low budget and plain dumb. The graphics type for the characters is really low quality compared to the overall graphics of the game.

Music and sound FX. These just do their job but nothing more. No memorable music here and the SFX just blend in with the atmosphere. Some sound FX reminded me of the first Unreal game for some reason.

The enemies, are your generic alien types and all are very annoying because they can just randomly appear in front of you and outnumber you directly. Their attack types get some time to get used to,and you do need some patience with each. You cannot just rush everything because you will die extremely fast.

Gameplay and atmosphere. The game tries a dark and gritty atmosphere that initially delivers very well but it is just lost along the way. The flashlight object shadowing mechanic is very cool to look at but it gets old too quick. Overall the atmosphere is fairly decent, the game does tempt you to go back and finish it.

Regarding gameplay only. It is quite satisfying to roll over large amounts of aliens but there are several points when it just feels unpolished. You need to do a lot of barrel rolling to avoid instant kill and you need to be aware of your environment all the time because if you hit a wall or an object,the character fails to respond quickly enough,and this causes a delay in movement,delay which will most of the time get you killed. This “stuck syndrome” is met in a large number of times,and really brings the game down as especially in the outdoor environments, you can get stuck a lot in the terrain because there are invisible walls in the middle of the map or the terrain was intended to be unpassable but on the map it looks just normal walking terrain. The gameplay overall feels initially good but gets repetitive and feels too hard at some points.

The weapons to me were very disappointing. While the game does have some sort of upgrade system to keep things interesting, I found myself way too many times using the standard pistol with unlimited ammo because everything else has very scarce ammo. Speaking of weapons, most of them seem very ineffective to the aliens. You waste an entire magazine on one enemy at times. Now this beeing good or bad,it is debateble. It does add a survival element to the game, but this element feels like it just happen to be in the game. Does not seem an intended behaivour. The ammo supplies are low, the weapons are largely ineffective and the only thing that keeps this aspect up is the upgrade system,which turns like a chore fast. It’s does not feel crucial on what type of upgrades you need to take.
Throughout the game you get upgrade parts to upgarde the weapons, which is a bit refreshing but again,gets old fast and also you find several computer terminals that fill in on the back story.

After managing to finish the game, I realized that the atmospheric music was much better than what it was initially and also what seemed to be a generic military/alien invasion had quite an interesting twist in the end. The story seemed stale throught the game but the ending was really weird to witness. Also with the right upgrades,the weapons DO seem to deliver some punch ,but for me it was still a bit of a disappointment.

I will recommend this game to fans of the genre and even to people that just want something new. Be advised, that the game is good but it is definetely not great, it does have the weight of a budget title all over it, but in the end it manages to deliver.

I want to like this game more than I actually do. Overall, it's fun, which is the point, and why I clicked the Recommend button, but there are some flaws that detract from the amount of fun I could be having.

First, the graphics. They may seem slightly dated, but that isn't the issue. The biggest problem is the lack of options. My screen is 16:9, but the screen seems to display in something like 2.33:1, so everything is squished. Another problem is the lack of antialiasing, and while this might not be as noticeable if I could set the graphics to my screen's native resolution, the two problems combined really take away from the immersion.

Second, the controls. I've tried both keyboard/mouse and a 360 controller, the latter of which seems like the better option for an isometric shooter. The default values are difficult to use at best. Why are the triggers used for rotating the camera instead of firing weapons? And why is the camera so overly touchy? When I switched to the KB/mouse combo, the WASD setup was fine for most things, but camera rotation became such an issue that I simply avoided it.

I could make the writing and voice acting the third issue, and for some it may be problematic. I am a lover of B flicks however, so I didn't buy this game expecting a deep, rich story, or Hollywood A-list acting. This review is for the game ''Shadowgrounds''.

Linux:September 16, 2009,Mac OS X:April 13, 2011,Steam:May 8, 2006
Genre:Single player,local co-op top-down shooter(shoot em up)
Recap
There's not much to tell since it's a really straightforward game.The plot is really simple-some would say cliché- about Wesley Tyler, a senior mechanic on the IGTO Repair Base on Jupiter's satellite Ganymede,whose responsibility is to repair various systems.During his work he finds some dead bodies,then finds a pistol and other forms of weaponry and -oh the irony- alliens begin to invade the planet(in this case the satellite).You have to progress through 11 levels,save some troopers,destroy some engines and kill many(many many many) hostile aliens.In the end(spoiler alert) you will find out that the aliens really weren't that bad,though they had fallen victims to their own greed and destroyed their own home planet and most of their own race with that kind of technology.That's why they've been monitoring the human race and when they found out they would use that kind of energy.Our hero and his friends decide to give the AMEW bomb back and save eventually the entire solar system(surprising right?)
Pros: 1)Simple yet enjoyable story,2)Pleasant time consuming(and yes that's a pro for me),3)Fairly cheap
Cons:1)Limited, no-brainer skill costumization,2)Not much of a challenge(aliens and alien bosses are really easy even at the hardest difficulty,3)Lame voice acting and some of the lamest quotes in gaming.
Overall a nice pleasant time consuming game.I recommend this game but not for the people who need a challenge though.
Thank you Frozenbyte Developers for this game :).

reviewText:
I saw this game on sale and thought it looked similar to Alien Swarm (which has provided me with countless hours of entertainment) so I purchased this. At first I didn't like the feel of the controls and was starting to think it was a waste of money. I perservered and plowed on with the campaign. Before I knew it I was completely immersed into the story line and had come to terms with the controls. I think the initial dislike was the fact that the first Aliens you encounter are probably the hardest to shoot out of everything else in the game.

The story line was engaging enough for my liking but was somewhat predictable and recycled sci fi adventure themes resounded throughout. There were some extremely well made parts of the game that surprised me and brought a huge smile to my face. (The part where you fight loads of Aliens inside the Rave music room is EPIC. Loved the fact when outside of the main room you could hear the music muffled in the background. Very atmospheric.) The soundtrack was absolutely awesome. The dialogue in some sections between characters was a little forced and unnatural but they couldn't just stand in silence I guess.

It took me just a little over 8 hours to complete the entire campaign and I enjoyed every moment of it. Definitely worth a buy! I did however encounter a bug on 1 chapter which was literally right at the end of said chapter causing me to have to restart that particular chapter which irritated me somewhat. It was after prepping the space ship and the automated defense robots activate and come after you. I was on around 11hp after some poor combat vs the big ♥♥♥♥ers with forcefields and guns for hands. This caused me to die despite my best efforts vs the 2 automated defense robots and when I revived I was stuck behind the 2 blast doors you needed a key card for. This meant I could not get in to kill the robots and complete the chapter. Other than that it was a solid play and hugely enjoyable.

reviewText:
The game that made Frozenbyte studio famous, and gave them the means to make Trine series.

One of the most underrated, technologically advanced game at its time, the game still manages to look good and play well even today. All that for under 800 MB too!

The story behind the game is simple, think DOOM, but enticing and with a twist at the end. The gameplay is top-down shooter with RPG style upgrades. Plenty of guns with plenty of upgrades means plenty of action! =D

The studio behind it, Frozenbyte, is probably one of the best indie developers. Shadowgrounds was released back in 2006, but they are still supporting the game and helping players on Steam forums etc.

The ONLY downside of this game is, really, the lack of coop over internet. There IS coop, but sadly it's local 2-4 player only, so you'll need many gamepads lol.

Overall strongly recommand this game to everyone. Especially now it's dirt cheap, and when it goes on sale it costs like nothing lol.

reviewText:
Shadowgrounds from Frozenbyte is a top-down sci-fi alien murderfest.  Shoot thousands of giant bugs and cyborg spiders with a multitude of different weapons.

Humanity has successfully terraformed Ganymede, and there is a burgeoning scientific and military presence establishing a foothold here.  But when the power generator is mysteriously sent offline, the mechanic Tyler has to go investigate.  Turns out there is blood smeared everywhere and bodies lying all over.  What he finds after that will change the course of history.  The story tries to take itself seriously, but in all honesty, it isn’t very original or all that engaging.  But it’s a good enough excuse for indiscriminately blowing up aliens.

Shadowgrounds is a top-down shooter, which takes a few minutes to get used to, as atmospheric games like this usually are in first person.  The game is focused on exploring the different alien-infested buildings in each level, finding keycards to unlock the next section, and shooting anything that moves.  You’ll constantly be concerned with your ammo reserves (especially on boss levels, as bosses can take A LOT of damage) but for most of the game ammo is plentiful.  Enemies have an annoying tendency to be bullet sponges, requiring you to empty a clip or more into some of them in order to kill them.  You’ll never be completely helpless, as your pistol has infinite shots.  The other weapons are all unique and satisfying to use, each giving you different strategies to employ and allowing you an easier time of taking out certain enemies.  Dead aliens will sometimes drop upgrade parts, which you can spend to give your weapons new abilities like higher damage, rapid fire, or extended magazines.  You can read documents that have been left lying around on PDAs or on computers in order to figure out what is really going on, but it is completely optional, and frankly not all that interesting.

The visuals are pretty simplistic, and the textures of the different buildings do little to set themselves apart from one another.  But the way the game handles lighting is superb.  The smaller alien bugs will actually run away from you if your flashlight is on.  This is useful knowledge, but know that objects like crates or doors will block your flashlight just like in real life.  The way light bends (or more accurately, doesn’t) around corners is a surprisingly nice touch.  In later levels, you’ll come across invisible enemies that will flicker in the beam of your flashlight, giving an eerie screech as they try to dismember you.

The audio quality is passable, overall.  The voice acting is definitely the low point, as lines are delivered with over-the-top and unconvincing cheesiness.  The soundtrack is this cool hard rock techno you might find in a summer action movie, which fits the theme very well.  Enemy screeches and clanging objects will let you know what is coming once you learn how each enemy behaves.

The biggest issue with this game is that it really wants me to care about the story it is trying to tell, and while I enjoyed it near the end, it was quite diffult to get into.  The subpar voice acting doesn’t really help in that regard, but I enjoyed my time in Shadowgrounds.  The developers did a great job making levels seem just a little different from each other, which gives some uniqueness to each encounter.  In one, you’ll be defending a base full of survivors from waves of attackers, and in another you’ll be negotiating a twisting canyon as aliens climb down and surprise you.

Having said all that, do I recommend Shadowgrounds?  The easiest way I can describe it is that it feels like a poor man’s Halo.  Fun, frentic combat makes up for a lot of the game’s other faults, and playing it on Easy is a decent waste of a Saturday afternoon, but I wouldn’t say you’ll be missing out on much if you skip this game.

I didn't think I liked isometric shooters - then I played this one.  The controls took a brief getting-used-to, and once I had, I was roll-flipping-behind-the-back shotgunning aliens in 360 degrees.  So fun.

The sequel introduced physics objects - which I think is actually a very bad idea, as they briefly slow down the flow of time in the game on older computers.  Part of what makes this original Shadowgrounds so great is it's silky-smooth and consistent gameplay throughout.  Nothing drives me nuts more than inconsistent flow-of-time / speed-of-time in a game.  (I'm looking at YOU, EA.)  I'd much rather have simple graphics and solid-as-steel gameplay than super HD realism and feeling like some man behind the curtain is filddling with the universe's speed-dial, screwing up my reaction time.

Seriously.  Action games are all about reflexes, judging and anticipating movement - hitting stuff that moves with other stuff that moves.  If you were about to hit a baseball as it flies towards your bat at 92.6 miles an hour... and suddenly, 10 feet before it reaches you, just as you are releasing your wind-up... the ball decides to move at 84.5 mile an hour until it passes your already-swung bat, accelerating to an unexplainable 135 miles an hour as it no-clips through the wall.  No.

This game does not have that problem, so buy it - and relish in it's mindless alien-slaughtering, earth-saving glory.

UPDATE

While playing the game for the second time I had much more fun then on my first run. The game has a pretty good atmosphere, especially at the beginning when you still don't know what is going on and your arsenal is very limited. The dynamic shadows keep the tension up, since sometimes you are not sure if that was the enemy that moved or just the shadow. You can read personal logs on PDAs and computers and learn abut tragic deaths, fun jokes on the workplace while things were peaceful, and learn about what was happening before the events in the game. This is all just like in Doom 3, but it's still fun.

The soundtrack is pretty good and sets the mood just right, and when a large battle starts the music gets more energetic and makes you ready for the battle.

The maps are HUGE, some can take more than half an hour to finish, and first few levels are more open, so you can enter a building from various points. All the weapons are very fun to use and you can upgrade them. The upgrade system makes you explore the maps more, so you can kill more enemies and get the upgrade parts sooner.

There are not many enemies in the game, but they are all very different, and require slightly different tactics and weapons. Some run at you and jump, some get invisible and you need to use the flashlight to see them, some have shields on front, so you need to sneek from the back, some throw goo at you and slow you down... Unfortunatelly the AI is very limited, and sometimes they get stuck.

I enjoyed the story too, it is nothing groundbreaking, enough to give you some context and keep you going, but the ending was a surprise. I'm glad I replayed this game and now I think it is a much better game than I first thought.
